qas.question: What behaviors did the Taínos begin to adopt after years of mistreatment?
What did Taínos women start doing to their infants?
Why would ingesting untreated cassava be a bad idea?
How many years was a Taínos Cacique able to hold ou in the Baoruco Mountain Range?
Who was sent to negotiate a peace treaty with the rebels?

context: Following years of mistreatment, the Taínos began to adopt <a0_0>suicidal<a0_0/> behaviors, with women <a1_0>aborting or killing<a1_0/> their infants and men jumping from the cliffs or ingesting untreated cassava, a <a2_0>violent poison<a2_0/>. Eventually, a Taíno Cacique named Enriquillo managed to hold out in the Baoruco Mountain Range for <a3_0>thirteen<a3_0/> years, causing serious damage to the Spanish, Carib-held plantations and their Indian auxiliaries. Hearing of the seriousness of the revolt, Emperor Charles V (also King of Spain) sent captain <a4_0>Francisco Barrionuevo<a4_0/> to negotiate a peace treaty with the ever-increasing number of rebels. Two months later, after consultation with the Audencia of Santo Domingo, Enriquillo was offered any part of the island to live in peace.
